column4: hello all.  Using the ubuntu or kubuntu -alternate isos, does the text-based installer allow you to use existing disk partitions without formatting them?  the standard installers don't.
the standard installers allow that too.
but you can't install to an unformatted '/' and '/boot' partition.
that's what I need to get around
i don't think you can get around that.
nothing really important shoudl reside there IMO, except config files which you can back up and restore
I've got /oldroot and /oldhome which I don't really have the means to backup or put elsewhere at the moment.
any idea about the text based installer on the alternate cds?
the text-based installer doesn't do magic :) you still have to formt your root and boot partitions.
honestly, it doesn't seem like magic to me.  ubuntu is debian based isn't?  even the debian installer does it
debian installer allows install to an unclean boot partition?... hmmm
archlinux does, and gentoo's text installer does
i know that redhat does that too, but i don't recall seeing debian or ubuntu do that.
deb definitely does.  I've done it 3 or 4 times today, heheh
